content.text: Describe the vertical motion of the skydiver between time = 0 and time = 20 s
Determine the maximum vertical speed of the skydiver
maximum speed =   .........  m/s
Determine the point, A, B, C, D or E, at which the skydiver opens her parachute
Determine the distance the skydiver falls between time = 50 s and time = 80 s
distance =   .........  m
Using the information from Fig. 1.3:
On Fig. 1.4, write the name of the upward force on the dotted line above the upward force
Suggest a value for the upward force on the skydiver at time = 10 s
Determine the value of the upward force on the skydiver at time = 30 s
The weight of the skydiver is 750 N
The weight of the skydiver acts downwards, as shown in Fig. 1.4
While the skydiver is falling, another force acts upwards
The upward force varies as the skydiver falls
The weight of the skydiver is 750 N
Calculate the mass of the skydiver
A skydiver jumps from an aeroplane. She falls freely with her parachute closed; then she opens her parachute
Fig. 1.1 shows the skydiver falling freely with her parachute closed
Fig. 1.2 shows the skydiver falling with the parachute open
Fig. 1.2

State the name of the measuring device shown in Fig. 2.1
Determine the difference \(h\) between the mercury levels shown in Fig. 2.1
The atmospheric pressure is \(760 \text{mm}\) of mercury
Determine the pressure of the gas supply
Suggest why this measuring device uses mercury rather than coloured water
The gas supply is turned off and the device is disconnected from the gas supply. Both ends of the tube are open to the atmosphere
On Fig. 2.2, draw and label the levels of mercury in side A and in side B of the tube.
A device for measuring gas pressure is connected to a gas supply as shown in Fig. 2.1
the \(100^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) mark on the thermometer scale
the \(0^\circ \mathrm{C}\) mark on the thermometer scale
State the importance of the \(0^\circ \mathrm{C}\) and \(100^\circ \mathrm{C}\) marks on a thermometer scale
A liquid-in-glass thermometer has a scale with marks from \(- 10^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) to \(110^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
A student checks the accuracy of the thermometer
Describe how to check the accuracy of:
State the physical property that we use to measure temperature in a liquid-in-glass thermometer
State another physical property that we use to measure temperature
We can measure temperature by using physical properties that vary with temperature
State the name of the process that causes the puddles to disappear
Describe the process that causes the puddles to disappear
Use your ideas about molecules
A student designs a container to keep a hot liquid at a high temperature
The container is shown in Fig. 4.2
He finds that the liquid cools too quickly
Suggest two improvements to the design of the container which reduce the transfer of thermal energy from the hot liquid to its surroundings
For each suggestion, state the thermal transfer process that it reduces
suggestion 1
thermal transfer process
suggestion 2
thermal transfer process
Fig. 4.1 shows students walking to school. There are puddles of water on the ground
After school, the puddles have disappeared and the ground is dry
the amplitude of the wave
the wavelength of the wave
The diagram in Fig. 5.1 shows the profile (side view) of a water wave
State the letter which represents:
The water molecules move at right angles to the direction of travel of the water wave
State the name for this type of wave

Compare the speed of radio waves and visible light. Complete the sentence

Two of the regions are not labelled
the signal for satellite television broadcasting ....................................................
The different regions of the electromagnetic spectrum have different uses
State the region of the electromagnetic spectrum that is used for:

On Fig. 6.1, indicate the angle of reflection by drawing an X
State the law of reflection
Fig. 6.1 shows a ray of light striking a plane mirror
A candle is placed in front of a plane mirror. An image of the candle is formed in the mirror
Circle the words from the list that describe the image of the candle
**enlarged** **diminished** **same size** **upside-down** **upright**
On Fig. 6.2, draw a line to indicate the path of the red light travelling through the glass prism and emerging into the air
Explain why the red light follows the path you have drawn in (c)(i)
Fig. 6.2 shows a ray of red light striking one side of a glass prism

Suggest one use for this type of magnet
Compare the effect of using a steel rod instead of an iron rod in the arrangement in Fig. 7.1
The steel rod is the same size as the iron rod
Compare the effect of using a copper rod instead of an iron rod in the arrangement in Fig. 7.1
The copper rod is the same size as the iron rod
Fig. 7.1 shows an arrangement that can produce a magnet

Scientists find an ancient wooden spoon. They find that the spoon contains 2000 atoms of carbon-14

age of spoon =   .........  years
